ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot from the zena rommett floor-barre technique from having movement practice that incorporated it every class. I also got to learn about some interesting ways to approach dance and to approach understanding dance from architecture to visual art techniques to physical therapy for dancers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: super inviting for all levels of prior dance experience, doesn't require much of you outside of class time, very interdisciplinary, some cool guest speakers

weaknesses: not well organized, didn't really have a syllabus so unclear in terms of deadlines and prompts for assignments, felt a bit repetitive in terms of prompts for papers and the moves we did in floor-barre each class

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
succeeded: surprisingly went well to do floor-barre on zoom, showing videos of final assignment instead of performing it live, breaks in the middle of class was huge for screen time/zoom fatigue!!

could be improved: was hard to overcome wifi issues, figuring out how to play music and speak to us at the same time (if possible) because zoom doesn't really know how to prioritize sound if there are multiple sounds so her voice would get lost or the music would cut out when she tried to give us directions while playing music, develop some sort of policy that allows students to have their camera off

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I might recommend this class when things are in person again. I think that there were aspects of the course that would be great if the class could meet in person (movement practice) and I felt like class discussions might be a bit better if the class could establish some sort of rapport. Professor Robinson is lovely but I'm honestly not really sure what exactly I learned.

i would recommend it if you're looking for a class that's a bit slower paced and not as intensive, but also allows you to get some movement regularly in your schedule since there are so few dance classes formally offered at yale. however, i would check for a syllabus and see if the course has gained a clearer structure because i think that would've made my experience of the class better. i also think the lack of clarity and structure was partially a product of covid and difficulties transitioning everything online in a way that worked for professor robinson.
